structured_predictions.CHIEF COMPLAINT: The patient, Roy, presents with a history of depression, high blood pressure, and recent concerns about his weight gain and recent blood pressure readings.
structured_predictions.VITALS: No specific vital signs are mentioned in the conversation.
structured_predictions.PHYSICAL EXAM: On examination, Roy's lungs are clear, heart is regular with a grade two systolic ejection murmur, extremities show no edema, and he has gained some weight. No other abnormalities were noted.
structured_predictions.RESULTS: No laboratory or diagnostic test results are mentioned in the conversation.
structured_predictions.ASSESSMENT: Roy's ongoing depression is stable on zoloft 50 mg daily, though he reports occasional sleep disturbances. His high blood pressure remains under control with lisinopril 5 mg daily. The recent weight gain and elevated blood pressure readings are concerning and may require further investigation.
structured_predictions.PLAN: Roy is advised to adhere to a healthier diet to address his weight gain. His current medications, zoloft and lisinopril, will remain unchanged. He is scheduled for a follow-up appointment in one month and then in three months for an a1c check to monitor his overall health status. A prescription for zoloft 50 mg daily is refilled for him.
structured_predictions.INSTRUCTIONS:
Roy is instructed to maintain a healthy diet, continue taking his medications as prescribed, and attend his upcoming appointments for monitoring and further evaluation. He should report any significant changes in his condition or symptoms to his healthcare provider.  CHIEF COMPLAINT
The patient, Roy, presents with a history of depression, high blood pressure, and recent concerns about his weight gain and recent blood pressure readings.

structured_predictions.HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient, a 57-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting, hyperlipidemia, and OCD, presented with symptoms of an upper respiratory infection. He reported starting to feel unwell about a week ago, with initial cold-like symptoms that progressed to involve his chest in the last two to three days. The patient denied any sinus pain, post-nasal drip, recent fevers, or shortness of breath. He had received both doses of the COVID-19 vaccine and reported no one else in his household was ill. He also denied any recent chest pain or difficulty exercising.
structured_predictions.PHYSICAL EXAM: On examination, the patient exhibited cervical lymphadenopathy, bilateral ronchi in the lungs, and wheezing. No other abnormalities were noted during the physical exam.
structured_predictions.RESULTS:
COVID-19 test result: Positive
Lipid panel: Cholesterol levels within normal limits
No other significant results mentioned.
structured_predictions.ASSESSMENT: The patient was diagnosed with a mild COVID-19 infection despite vaccination, likely due to a breakthrough case. His high cholesterol levels remained stable, and his coronary artery bypass grafting appeared to be under control with ongoing exercise and no chest pain.
structured_predictions.PLAN: The patient was advised to quarantine for 10 days and avoid contact with household members. He was instructed to take time off work and to call the doctor if his symptoms worsened. For his high cholesterol, he was to continue taking Crestor 20 mg daily and maintain a healthy diet. A follow-up lipid panel was scheduled in six months. Additionally, a stress test was planned in six months to monitor his coronary artery disease status.
structured_predictions.INSTRUCTIONS:
- Quarantine for 10 days
- Avoid contact with household members
- Take time off work
- Call doctor if symptoms worsen
- Continue taking Crestor 20 mg daily
- Maintain a healthy diet
- Follow up with lipid panel in six months
- Schedule a stress test in six months.

structured_predictions.CHIEF COMPLAINT: The patient, James, reports joint pain, specifically in his knees, which has worsened over the past three to four days. He attributes this to increased biking activity, with symptoms being more pronounced in the mornings and towards the evening.
structured_predictions.HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: James, a 57-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease and lupus, presents with bilateral knee pain. He describes the pain as stiffness and soreness upon waking, which improves slightly throughout the day. There is no swelling or redness noted during the day, although he mentions the knees appear inflamed in the morning. No other joint involvement, such as elbows, wrists, or shoulders, is reported. There are no associated symptoms like fatigue, fever, or injury. His heart disease management includes daily aspirin and a history of stenting, with current medication adherence to Crestor without issues. Lupus-related symptoms, such as kidney function, have been stable without recent issues.
structured_predictions.VITALS: No specific vital signs are mentioned in the conversation.
structured_predictions.PHYSICAL EXAM: On examination, James exhibits bilateral knee edema and slight erythema, with a slight effusion noted on the right knee. Pain is elicited on palpation of the right knee, and there is decreased range of motion in both knees. A two out of six systolic ejection murmur is heard, consistent with previous findings. Lungs are clear, and the ECG shows no abnormalities.
structured_predictions.RESULTS:
- Right knee X-ray: No bony abnormalities or fractures.
- Most recent ECG: Normal.
- Autoimmune panel ordered (pending results).
- Lipid panel and echocardiogram ordered
structured_predictions.ASSESSMENT: The differential diagnosis includes a possible lupus flare given the joint symptoms and systemic lupus history. The knee pain could also be related to overuse from increased biking activity. The coronary artery disease and lupus are well-managed, with no immediate concerns from the ECG or physical examination.
structured_predictions.PLAN:
- Order an autoimmune panel to evaluate for lupus flare.
- Order a lipid panel and echocardiogram to monitor coronary artery disease.
- Review and adjust medications as necessary based on test results.
- Educate the patient on the importance of gradual increase in physical activity and proper hydration to prevent exacerbation of symptoms.
structured_predictions.INSTRUCTIONS:
- The patient is advised to continue his current medications and maintain a balanced diet.
- Gradual increase in biking activity should be avoided until further evaluation.
- Follow-up appointment scheduled after the results of the autoimmune panel, lipid panel, and echocardiogram are available.
- Contact the clinic if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop.  CHIEF COMPLAINT
The patient, James, reports joint pain, specifically in his knees, which has worsened over the past three to four days. He attributes this to increased biking activity, with symptoms being more pronounced in the mornings and towards the evening.

structured_predictions.CHIEF COMPLAINT: The patient, Natalie, presented for a check-up due to an abnormal lab result showing elevated blood sugars.
structured_predictions.HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Natalie, a 39-year-old female, reports a history of high blood pressure, diabetes, and ACL repair. She recently had routine blood work that showed elevated blood sugars, prompting her visit. She denies any symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Her diet for diabetes has been good, and she has been adhering to her exercise regimen of power walking daily. She has been stable on her current medications and has not experienced any issues with her ACL repair.
structured_predictions.VITALS: Blood pressure is within normal limits, oxygen saturation is excellent, and temperature is normal. No abnormal findings in the physical examination.
structured_predictions.PHYSICAL EXAM: On examination, Natalie's heart sounds normal, lungs are clear, and she has a systolic ejection murmur graded at three over six. Her abdomen is soft with no swelling or tenderness, and there is no edema in the extremities.
structured_predictions.RESULTS: Recent lab results indicate an elevated hemoglobin A1c of 8.1%. Other labs, including a complete blood count (CBC) and comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), are pending. A lipid panel will also be ordered.
structured_predictions.ASSESSMENT: Natalie is diagnosed with poorly controlled diabetes, evidenced by the elevated hemoglobin A1c. She is currently on metformin 1,000 mg twice daily. Her high blood pressure and ACL repair are stable, with no current issues reported.
structured_predictions.PLAN: The plan includes adding Jardiance (empagliflozin) 10 mg daily to her current regimen of metformin. A lipid panel and additional blood work will be conducted to further assess her metabolic profile. She will continue her current medications for hypertension and maintain her exercise regimen. Follow-up appointment will be
structured_predictions.INSTRUCTIONS:
Natalie is instructed to continue her current medications and diet, monitor her blood pressure at home, and maintain her exercise routine. She is advised to avoid sugars and maintain a healthy weight. She should report any new symptoms or changes in her condition to her healthcare provider. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in four weeks to review her progress and adjust her treatment plan as needed.  CHIEF COMPLAINT
The patient, Natalie, presented for a check-up due to an abnormal lab result showing elevated blood sugars.

references:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

History of depression.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Roy Sanchez is a 50-year-old male who comes in with a history of depressionand high blood pressure. He presents today for abnormal labs.

He states it has been a pretty stressful winter and spring, as they have been very short-staffed at work. The patient admits to recent weight gain. He has been hosting friends over vacation and at the beach this summer so the diet is off the charts out the window.

The patient has a history of depression and is doing well. He has been consistent with utilizing his Zoloft 50 mg a day. The patient states this has been a challenging year and a half. He is sleeping okay at night, occasionally waking up at 5 a.m. Denies thoughts of self-harm or suicidal ideation

His high blood pressure has been under good control recently

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses weight gain.
• Psychiatric:   Endorses stress.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate. Grade 2 systolic ejection murmur. No gallops or rubs. No extra heart sounds.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Roy Sanchez is a 50-year-old male who comes in with a history of depression and high blood pressure. He presents today for abnormal labs.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is well controlled at this time.
• Medical Treatment: He will continue lisinopril 5 mg daily.

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: He is doing well with Zoloft 50 mg daily.
• Medical Treatment: He will continue Zoloft 50 mg daily. This was refilled today.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Upper respiratory infection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan Harris is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery bypass grafting, hyperlipidemia, and OCD, who presents with an upper respiratory infection.

The patient reports that about a week ago he started to get a cold, which has worsened in the last 2 or 3 days. He endorses some postnasal drip for the beginning of the week, however, it has seemed to move into his chest. He denies chest pain other than his chest congestion. He was able to exercise prior to getting sick. He denies anyone else being sick in his house. He denies fever and shortness of breath.

Regarding his high cholesterol, he states he has been pretty good for the most part. He did a little travel over the last week or so and his diet was not great but for the most part it is pretty good. He is on Crestor 20 mg a day and is tolerating it well. He denies any muscle aches. He had his bypass grafting last year and is doing great.

The patient is fully vaccinated for COVID-19.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses post nasal drip.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest congestion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Psychiatric: Endorses obsessive compulsive disorder.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: Positive cervical lymphadenopathy
• Respiratory: Rhonchi and wheezing bilaterally.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Oxygen Saturation: 96%.

RESULTS

Lipid panel: Within normal limits.

COVID-19 test: Positive

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan Harris is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery bypass grafting, hyperlipidemia, and OCD who presents today for upper respiratory symptoms.

COVID-19 Positive.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with upper respiratory symptoms and his COVID-19 test was positive today. He has received both doses of the vaccination. His symptoms seem to be very mild at this time. His oxygenation is good at 96%.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised him to quarantine for 10 days and we discussed that he should try to avoid family members. I asked him to call me if his symptoms worsen.

Hypercholesterolemia.
• Medical Reasoning: He is doing well on Crestor 20 mg once a day. His cholesterol looked good on his most recent lipid panel.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged him to continue to watch his diet.
• Additional Testing: We will go ahead and order another lipid panel for 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: He can continue Crestor 20 mg once a day.

History of coronary artery bypass grafting.
• Medical Reasoning: He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting approximately 1 year ago. His coronary artery disease seems to be under control currently. He denies chest pain.
• Additional Testing: We will do a stress test in 6 months.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Joint pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. James Moore is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease and lupus, who presents today with some joint pain.

The patient reports he has been " putting a few more miles on the bike each day ". His bilateral knees have been sore in the last 3 to 4 days. He states his bilateral knees are equally painful. He notes stiffness and soreness in the morning and, by the end of the day, he feels the same sensation. He endorses swelling and redness in his knees which reduces in severity by the afternoon. The patient denies any other associated fatigue. He denies any injury to his knees. He denies pain in any other joints including his elbows, wrists, or shoulders.

In regards to his coronary artery disease, Mr. Moore states he is compliant with his aspirin and Crestor. He denies chest pain or shortness of breath.

The patient denies recent symptoms related to his lupus over the last year.

He denies fever, chills, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomitting.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses joint pain, stiffness, swelling, and erythema in bilateral knees.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Edema and slight erythema of bilateral knees. Slight effusion of the right knee with pain to palpation. Decreased range of motion in bilateral knees.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right knee is unremarkable. No bony abnormalities or fractures were noted.

Electrocardiogram stable in comparison to last year.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. James Moore is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease and lupus, who presents today with some joint pain.

Lupus.
• Medical Reasoning: This has been stable and asymptomatic for the past year, but the patient reports increased joint pain and inflammation in his bilateral knees lately. ​His recent knee x-ray was unremarkable, so I am concerned that this is a lupus flare.
• Additional Testing: We will order an autoimmune panel for further evaluation.

Coronary artery disease.
• Medical Reasoning: He is asymptomatic at this time. He has discontinued Plavix but continues with daily aspirin and Crestor. His recent EKG was unremarkable.
• Additional Testing: We will order a lipid panel and a repeat echocardiogram.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current regimen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Check up for abnormal labs.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Natalie Price is a 39-year-old female here today for a check up for an abnormal labs. She has a history of high blood pressure, diabetes type 2, and right ACL repair.

The patient states she had routine blood work done last week and they said her blood sugars were high. She was instructed to follow up to get some more work done. She denies having any symptoms.

Regarding her diabetes, her diet has been really great lately. She has been avoiding sugars and watching her weight. The patient is power walking 30 minutes every day. She is checking her blood sugars every morning. The patient has continued to utilize metformin 1000 mg a day, which was increased at her last visit.

She states her high blood pressure has been stable with lisinopril. The patient has a cuff at home to measure her blood pressure herself.

Regarding her knee, she had an ACL repair on her right knee about 5 years ago and everything has been going well. She has not had any issues with mobility.

She denies chest pain, shortness of breath, vomiting, diarrhea, headaches, and abdominal pain. She denies any difficulty urinating or burning when she urinates.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Genitourinary: Denies urinary pain.
• Neurological: Denies headaches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Head and Face: Normocephalic and atraumatic.
• Neck: Supple without thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy. No carotid bruits appreciable.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen is soft and nondistended.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.1.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Natalie Price is a 39-year-old female with a history of high blood pressure, diabetes type 2, and right ACL repair. She presents today for evaluation following abnormal labs.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: She is asymptomatic but her recent lab work demonstrated an elevated hemoglobin A1c of 8.1. She has been compliant with metformin 1000 mg daily, dietary modifications, and monitoring her blood glucose levels at home.
• Additional Testing: We will check her CBC, CMP, and lipid panel.
• Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg daily. Initiate Jardiance 10 mg daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged her to follow her dietary modifications closely.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: This is stable and well-controlled on her current dose of lisinopril. She does monitor her blood pressures at home.
• Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril at current dose.

Status post right ACL repair.
• Medical Reasoning: She is doing well postoperatively.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue with her physical activity and exercise regimen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
